elements.content: To develop potential metal–organic frameworks (MOFs) for 2,4,6-trinitrophenol (TNP) detection, an amino-functionalized Zn-MOF, [NH2(CH3)2]­[Zn4O­(bpt)2(bdc-NH2)0.5]·5DMF (where H3bpt = biphenyl-3,4′,5-tricarboxylate, H2bdc-NH2 = 2-aminoterephthalic acid, and DMF = N,N-dimethylformamide), has been designed theoretically and synthesized experimentally. Its structure is composed of Zn4O­(CO2)7 secondary building units linked by mixed ligands, exhibiting a three-dimensional framework. Fluorescence exploration revealed that the amino-functionalized Zn-MOF shows high selectivity and sensitivity for TNP, which agrees well with the predictions of theoretical simulations. This work provides a suitable means to develop new potential MOFs for TNP detection performance with a combination of experimental and theoretical perspectives.
elements.clean_text: To develop potential metal-organic frameworks (MOFs) for 2,4,6-trinitrophenol (TNP) detection, an amino-functionalized Zn-MOF, [NH2(CH3)2][Zn4O(bpt)2(bdc-NH2)0.5]⋅5DMF (where H3bpt = biphenyl-3,4',5-tricarboxylate, H2bdc-NH2 = 2-aminoterephthalic acid, and DMF = N,N-dimethylformamide), has been designed theoretically and synthesized experimentally. Its structure is composed of Zn4O(CO2)7 secondary building units linked by mixed ligands, exhibiting a three-dimensional framework. Fluorescence exploration revealed that the amino-functionalized Zn-MOF shows high selectivity and sensitivity for TNP, which agrees well with the predictions of theoretical simulations. This work provides a suitable means to develop new potential MOFs for TNP detection performance with a combination of experimental and theoretical perspectives.

elements.content: Detection of nitro explosives including nitromethane (NM), nitrobenzene (NB), 2,6-dinitrotoluene (2,6-DNT), dinitrobenzene (DNB), and 2,4,6-trinitrophenol (TNP), which are common ingredients used in industrial explosives, plays a crucial role in human security and thus has been of wide concern in recent years. Of all the nitro explosives, TNP has been paid the most attention due to its high explosive power. Additionally, TNP is also recognized as a highly toxic pollutant. TNP contamination in groundwater and soil not only induces severe health problems but also results in miserable environmental pollution. As a consequence, there is an urgent need to detect TNP with high selectivity and sensitivity. Current explosive detection methods (canines or sophisticated instruments) are high-cost, complicated, and have portability problems during practical use. Recently, it is noteworthy that fluorescence-based chemical sensors have obtained intense attention because of their speed, high sensitivity, and easily detectable signals. Materials like conjugated polymers, nanoparticles, and metal complexes have been utilized for fluorescence-based detection of nitro explosives.
elements.clean_text:
Introduction

Detection of nitro explosives including nitromethane (NM), nitrobenzene (NB), 2,6-dinitrotoluene (2,6-DNT), dinitrobenzene (DNB), and 2,4,6-trinitrophenol (TNP), which are common ingredients used in industrial explosives, plays a crucial role in human security and thus has been of wide concern in recent years. Of all the nitro explosives, TNP has been paid the most attention due to its high explosive power. Additionally, TNP is also recognized as a highly toxic pollutant. TNP contamination in groundwater and soil not only induces severe health problems but also results in miserable environmental pollution. As a consequence, there is an urgent need to detect TNP with high selectivity and sensitivity. Current explosive detection methods (canines or sophisticated instruments) are high-cost, complicated, and have portability problems during practical use. Recently, it is noteworthy that fluorescence-based chemical sensors have obtained intense attention because of their speed, high sensitivity, and easily detectable signals. Materials like conjugated polymers, nanoparticles, and metal complexes have been utilized for fluorescence-based detection of nitro explosives.

elements.content: Among the diverse fluorescence-based sensors, metal–organic frameworks (MOFs) have been considered as the leading sensors due to their tunable porous nature and detectable fluorescence changes. To date, a number of MOF-based sensors have been employed for sensing of nitro explosives. Li and co-workers first reported a luminescent microporous MOF that was able to detect trace explosives in the vapor phase. Ghosh and co-workers reported a luminescent Cd-MOF showing highly selective detection of TNP. To obtain an efficient sensor for nitro explosives, rational design and preparation of targeted MOFs become a necessity. Generally, two design strategies are utilized to make materials with ideal properties: (i) Through careful design of raw materials, such as ligand and metal clusters, the chemical and physical properties of MOFs can be finely modulated and materials with desired performance can be presented. However, this method exhibits uncertainty of empirical exploratory syntheses, owing to many possible chemistries. (ii) Theoretical simulation is an efficient means to design the most promising MOF candidates for detection prior to extensive experiments. This method has been successfully used in other fields such as MOF gas adsorption simulation, while their utilization for nitro explosives detection has been much less explored. New MOFs can be designed theoretically and their performance can be predicted by simulation. Thus, the theoretical simulation methods are able to further guide experiments through the design and prepare the potential MOFs for sensing nitro explosives.
elements.clean_text: Among the diverse fluorescence-based sensors, metal-organic frameworks (MOFs) have been considered as the leading sensors due to their tunable porous nature and detectable fluorescence changes. To date, a number of MOF-based sensors have been employed for sensing of nitro explosives. Li and co-workers first reported a luminescent microporous MOF that was able to detect trace explosives in the vapor phase. Ghosh and co-workers reported a luminescent Cd-MOF showing highly selective detection of TNP. To obtain an efficient sensor for nitro explosives, rational design and preparation of targeted MOFs become a necessity. Generally, two design strategies are utilized to make materials with ideal properties: (i) Through careful design of raw materials, such as ligand and metal clusters, the chemical and physical properties of MOFs can be finely modulated and materials with desired performance can be presented. However, this method exhibits uncertainty of empirical exploratory syntheses, owing to many possible chemistries. (ii) Theoretical simulation is an efficient means to design the most promising MOF candidates for detection prior to extensive experiments. This method has been successfully used in other fields such as MOF gas adsorption simulation, while their utilization for nitro explosives detection has been much less explored. New MOFs can be designed theoretically and their performance can be predicted by simulation. Thus, the theoretical simulation methods are able to further guide experiments through the design and prepare the potential MOFs for sensing nitro explosives.

elements.content: In this work, with a combination of theoretical prediction and experimental synthesis, two MOFs, [NH2(CH3)2]­[Zn4O­(bpt)2(bdc)0.5]·5DMF (1) and [NH2(CH3)2]­[Zn4O­(bpt)2(bdc-NH2)0.5]·5DMF (2) (where H3bpt = biphenyl-3,4′,5-tricarboxylate, H2bdc = terephthalic acid, and DMF = N,N-dimethylformamide), have been designed and synthesized. Their luminescent properties for sensing nitro explosives are studied systemically. Compound 2 exhibits higher selectivity and sensitivity for TNP compared to 1.
elements.clean_text: In this work, with a combination of theoretical prediction and experimental synthesis, two MOFs, [NH2(CH3)2][Zn4O(bpt)2(bdc)0.5]⋅5DMF (1) and [NH2(CH3)2][Zn4O(bpt)2(bdc-NH2)0.5]⋅5DMF (2) (where H3bpt = biphenyl-3,4',5-tricarboxylate, H2bdc = terephthalic acid, and DMF = N,N-dimethylformamide), have been designed and synthesized. Their luminescent properties for sensing nitro explosives are studied systemically. Compound 2 exhibits higher selectivity and sensitivity for TNP compared to 1.

elements.content: A mixture of Zn­(NO3)2·6H2O (60 mg, 0.2 mmol), H3bpt (26 mg, 0.1 mmol), and H2bdc (3 mg, 0.015 mmol) in 5 mL of DMF was stirred for 30 min in a vial (20 mL) with the addition of 100 μL of HBF4 (40%). The vial was sealed into a Teflon-lined stainless steel vessel and heated at 120 °C for 3 days. After slow cooling to room temperature, colorless crystals of 1 were collected, washed with DMF, and dried in air. Yield 61% (based on H3bpt). Anal. Calcd (%) for [NH2(CH3)2]­[Zn4O­(bpt)2(bdc)0.5]·5DMF: C, 45.80; H, 4.45; N, 6.28. Found: C, 45.54; H, 4.29; N, 6.01.
elements.clean_text:
Experimental Section

Synthesis of 1 

A mixture of Zn(NO3)2⋅6H2O (60 mg, 0.2 mmol), H3bpt (26 mg, 0.1 mmol), and H2bdc (3 mg, 0.015 mmol) in 5 mL of DMF was stirred for 30 min in a vial (20 mL) with the addition of 100 μL of HBF4 (40%). The vial was sealed into a Teflon-lined stainless steel vessel and heated at 120 °C for 3 days. After slow cooling to room temperature, colorless crystals of 1 were collected, washed with DMF, and dried in air. Yield 61% (based on H3bpt). Anal. Calcd (%) for [NH2(CH3)2][Zn4O(bpt)2(bdc)0.5]⋅5DMF: C, 45.80; H, 4.45; N, 6.28. Found: C, 45.54; H, 4.29; N, 6.01.

elements.content: A mixture of Zn­(NO3)2·6H2O (60 mg, 0.2 mmol), H3bpt (26 mg, 0.1 mmol), and H2bdc-NH2 (3 mg, 0.015 mmol) in 5 mL of DMF was stirred for 30 min in a vial (20 mL) with the addition of 50 μL of HBF4 (40%). The vial was sealed into a Teflon-lined stainless steel vessel and heated at 120 °C for 3 days. After slow cooling to room temperature, colorless crystals of 2 were collected, washed with DMF, and dried in air. Yield 57% (based on H3bpt). Anal. Calcd (%) for [NH2(CH3)2]­[Zn4O­(bpt)2(bdc-NH2)0.5]·5DMF: C, 45.54; H, 4.46; N, 6.77. Found: C, 45.40; H, 4.71; N, 6.55.
elements.clean_text:
Synthesis of 2 

A mixture of Zn(NO3)2⋅6H2O (60 mg, 0.2 mmol), H3bpt (26 mg, 0.1 mmol), and H2bdc-NH2 (3 mg, 0.015 mmol) in 5 mL of DMF was stirred for 30 min in a vial (20 mL) with the addition of 50 μL of HBF4 (40%). The vial was sealed into a Teflon-lined stainless steel vessel and heated at 120 °C for 3 days. After slow cooling to room temperature, colorless crystals of 2 were collected, washed with DMF, and dried in air. Yield 57% (based on H3bpt). Anal. Calcd (%) for [NH2(CH3)2][Zn4O(bpt)2(bdc-NH2)0.5]⋅5DMF: C, 45.54; H, 4.46; N, 6.77. Found: C, 45.40; H, 4.71; N, 6.55.

elements.content: We define a scheme for designing a target MOF with superior detection performance for nitro explosives by combining theoretical prediction and experimental synthesis methods. In order to predict the performance of the target MOF, we first attempt to model the hypothetical frameworks that are favorable for nitro explosives detection. We herein take a strategy aimed at modifying the reported or synthesized structures to fabricate the target MOF for nitro explosives detection. In general, the nitro explosives detection performance of MOFs is predominantly governed by four factors: (1) MOFs possessing luminescent properties are essential for sensing as a result of the detectable changes in luminescent characteristics. (2) Use of highly conjugated linkers is an effective method to construct MOFs that are considered to be crucial in detection of nitro explosives because of electron deficiency of nitro explosives known as fluorescence quenchers. (3) Suitable channels also play a key role in the nitro explosives sensing performance, permitting easy diffusion of analyte inside the channel. (4) Absolutely, the role of noncovalent interactions (e.g., electrostatic interactions, π–π interactions) cannot be ignored. The possible interaction between analyte and the internal surface of the framework can give rise to improved selective recognition. Through judicious selection of our previous synthesized structure, we chose the Zn-MOF as a parent MOF to explore nitro explosives detection, although the structure is similar to that reported recently by Kitagawa and co-workers and Su and co-workers. We were motivated to use this Zn-MOF as the parent MOF owing to the following beneficial properties: (i) its mixed highly conjugated linkers can enhance the electron density of the frameworks; (ii) its inherent porosity matches well with the TNP analyte; and (iii) its outstanding luminescence properties are beneficial for recognizing fluorescence response. However, the fluorescence exploration of Zn-MOF reveals that it has general detection ability for TNP. A possible reason might be that the interaction between TNP analyte and host framework is weak. In other words, there is no special binding site within the framework to interact with the TNP analyte. To further improve TNP detection performance, it is possible to introduce functional groups within the MOF structure. Alternatively, -NO2, -NH2, -OH, or -CH3 groups can act as binding sites in the parent Zn-MOF. We consider that the -NH2 group might be the best binding site, because of its electron-donor as well as hydrogen-bonding interactions with TNP. To predict TNP detection performance for amino-functionalized Zn-MOF, we carried out periodic density functional theoretical calculations to determine the adsorption energy of TNP. For comparison, the TNP detection performance of the parent Zn-MOF was also predicted. The adsorption energy of TNP in two MOFs is calculated as follows: E ads = E total − ( E MOF + E mol ) where E total is the total adsorption energy of the system, E MOF is the total energy of Zn-MOF, E mol is the energy of adsorbate, and E ads is the calculated adsorption energy. According to this formula, smaller E ads indicates greater adsorption strength of MOF to molecule. The calculation results show that E ads of TNP in the amino-functionalized Zn-MOF (2) is −0.99 eV, which is much lower than the value of −0.21 eV in the parent Zn-MOF (1), suggesting that 2 has stronger adsorption ability to TNP than 1. In the optimized structure of TNP in 2, as shown in , the proton from the hydroxyl group of TNP binds to the amino group, and thus strong hydrogen-bonding interactions between the protonated amino group of MOF and the phenolic oxygen atom of TNP molecule contribute to the good adsorption ability of 2 to TNP. The theory predicts excellent TNP detection performance for 2 over 1; thus we plan to focus our experiments on 2.
elements.clean_text:
Results and Discussion

We define a scheme for designing a target MOF with superior detection performance for nitro explosives by combining theoretical prediction and experimental synthesis methods. In order to predict the performance of the target MOF, we first attempt to model the hypothetical frameworks that are favorable for nitro explosives detection. We herein take a strategy aimed at modifying the reported or synthesized structures to fabricate the target MOF for nitro explosives detection. In general, the nitro explosives detection performance of MOFs is predominantly governed by four factors: (1) MOFs possessing luminescent properties are essential for sensing as a result of the detectable changes in luminescent characteristics. (2) Use of highly conjugated linkers is an effective method to construct MOFs that are considered to be crucial in detection of nitro explosives because of electron deficiency of nitro explosives known as fluorescence quenchers. (3) Suitable channels also play a key role in the nitro explosives sensing performance, permitting easy diffusion of analyte inside the channel. (4) Absolutely, the role of noncovalent interactions (e.g., electrostatic interactions, π-π interactions) cannot be ignored. The possible interaction between analyte and the internal surface of the framework can give rise to improved selective recognition. Through judicious selection of our previous synthesized structure, we chose the Zn-MOF as a parent MOF to explore nitro explosives detection, although the structure is similar to that reported recently by Kitagawa and co-workers and Su and co-workers. We were motivated to use this Zn-MOF as the parent MOF owing to the following beneficial properties: (i) its mixed highly conjugated linkers can enhance the electron density of the frameworks; (ii) its inherent porosity matches well with the TNP analyte; and (iii) its outstanding luminescence properties are beneficial for recognizing fluorescence response. However, the fluorescence exploration of Zn-MOF reveals that it has general detection ability for TNP. A possible reason might be that the interaction between TNP analyte and host framework is weak. In other words, there is no special binding site within the framework to interact with the TNP analyte. To further improve TNP detection performance, it is possible to introduce functional groups within the MOF structure. Alternatively, -NO2, -NH2, -OH, or -CH3 groups can act as binding sites in the parent Zn-MOF. We consider that the -NH2 group might be the best binding site, because of its electron-donor as well as hydrogen-bonding interactions with TNP. To predict TNP detection performance for amino-functionalized Zn-MOF, we carried out periodic density functional theoretical calculations to determine the adsorption energy of TNP. For comparison, the TNP detection performance of the parent Zn-MOF was also predicted. The adsorption energy of TNP in two MOFs is calculated as follows:      E   ads   =   E   total   -  (   E   MOF   +   E   mol   )    where E total is the total adsorption energy of the system, E MOF is the total energy of Zn-MOF, E mol is the energy of adsorbate, and E ads is the calculated adsorption energy. According to this formula, smaller E ads indicates greater adsorption strength of MOF to molecule. The calculation results show that E ads of TNP in the amino-functionalized Zn-MOF (2) is -0.99 eV, which is much lower than the value of -0.21 eV in the parent Zn-MOF (1), suggesting that 2 has stronger adsorption ability to TNP than 1. In the optimized structure of TNP in 2, as shown in , the proton from the hydroxyl group of TNP binds to the amino group, and thus strong hydrogen-bonding interactions between the protonated amino group of MOF and the phenolic oxygen atom of TNP molecule contribute to the good adsorption ability of 2 to TNP. The theory predicts excellent TNP detection performance for 2 over 1; thus we plan to focus our experiments on 2.

elements.content: Optimized adsorption structure of TNP in 2.
elements.clean_text: 1  Optimized adsorption structure of TNP in 2.

elements.content: Motivated by the theoretical calculation results, we have synthesized 2 under similar synthetic conditions. At low concentration of HBF4, its presence promotes crystallinity and inhibits formation of amorphous precipitate. The powder X-ray diffraction (PXRD) pattern indicates that the crystal structures of 1 and 2 are isostructural (Figure S1). Therefore, the structure of 2 was described representatively. Compound 2 crystallizes in the monoclinic crystal system of the P21/n space group. The host framework of 2 is anionic and charge-balanced by (CH3)2NH2 +, resulting from decomposition of the DMF solvent. The asymmetric unit contains one Zn4(μ4-O) cluster, two deprotonated bpt ligands, and 1/2 deprotonated bdc-NH2 ligand. Each Zn4(μ4-O) cluster is surrounded by seven carboxylate groups from six H3bpt linkers and one bdc-NH2 to form a Zn4O­(CO2)7 secondary building unit (SBU). Four H3bpt and two bdc-NH2 ligands link six different Zn4O­(CO2)7 SBUs at the corners to form an octahedral cage. As a result, the octahedral cages are linked by H3bpt ligands into a three-dimensional (3D) porous framework (a,b). From a topological point of view, the Zn4O­(CO2)7 SBU can be simplified to a 7-connected node, and the bpt linker can be regarded as a 3-connected node. Thus, the structure of 2 can be described as a (3,7)-connected network with Schläfli symbol (4·52)2·(42·55·610·84) (c). As represented in d, there are three kinds of tiles: [62·82], [4·52·62], and [42·54]. After elimination of all guest molecules, the total accessible volume in 2 is 64.9% by the PLATON/VOID routine.
elements.clean_text: Motivated by the theoretical calculation results, we have synthesized 2 under similar synthetic conditions. At low concentration of HBF4, its presence promotes crystallinity and inhibits formation of amorphous precipitate. The powder X-ray diffraction (PXRD) pattern indicates that the crystal structures of 1 and 2 are isostructural (Figure S1). Therefore, the structure of 2 was described representatively. Compound 2 crystallizes in the monoclinic crystal system of the P21/n space group. The host framework of 2 is anionic and charge-balanced by (CH3)2NH2 +, resulting from decomposition of the DMF solvent. The asymmetric unit contains one Zn4(μ4-O) cluster, two deprotonated bpt ligands, and 1/2 deprotonated bdc-NH2 ligand. Each Zn4(μ4-O) cluster is surrounded by seven carboxylate groups from six H3bpt linkers and one bdc-NH2 to form a Zn4O(CO2)7 secondary building unit (SBU). Four H3bpt and two bdc-NH2 ligands link six different Zn4O(CO2)7 SBUs at the corners to form an octahedral cage. As a result, the octahedral cages are linked by H3bpt ligands into a three-dimensional (3D) porous framework (a,b). From a topological point of view, the Zn4O(CO2)7 SBU can be simplified to a 7-connected node, and the bpt linker can be regarded as a 3-connected node. Thus, the structure of 2 can be described as a (3,7)-connected network with Schläfli symbol (4⋅52)2⋅(42⋅55⋅610⋅84) (c). As represented in d, there are three kinds of tiles: [62⋅82], [4⋅52⋅62], and [42⋅54]. After elimination of all guest molecules, the total accessible volume in 2 is 64.9% by the PLATON/VOID routine.

elements.content: Structures for 2: (a) octahedral cages; (b) space-filling model of the framework; (c) (3,7)-connected topology network; (d) topological features of the compound displayed by tiles.
elements.clean_text: 2  Structures for 2: (a) octahedral cages; (b) space-filling model of the framework; (c) (3,7)-connected topology network; (d) topological features of the compound displayed by tiles.

elements.content: Experimental PXRD patterns of 1 and 2 agree well with the simulated pattern according to their single-crystal X-ray data, showing the purity of the synthesized products (Figure S1). Because 1 is isostructural with 2, we describe the thermogravimetric analysis of 2 representatively. Thermogravimetric analysis of 2 showed a weight loss of 31.41% before 250 °C, corresponding to the loss of all guest molecules (calculated 30.56%) (Figure S2). The framework started to collapse and decompose with increasing temperature. The final residue was ZnO (experimental 25.01%, calculated 24.20%). Compound 2 was rinsed with DMF followed by methanol in an experiment to give methanol-exchanged compound. The methanol-exchanged compound was dried at 120 °C under high vacuum for 10 h to give activated 2. The PXRD pattern indicated that the original framework of activated 2 was retained after activation (Figure S3). The characteristic peak of CO of DMF at 1666 cm–1 disappeared for activated 2, suggesting all DMF molecules are removed completely (Figure S4). The permanent porosity of activated 2 can be confirmed by N2 sorption at 77 K, showing type I sorption behavior (Figure S5). The Brunauer–Emmett–Teller (BET) surface area for 2 was calculated to be 407 m2·g–1.
elements.clean_text: Experimental PXRD patterns of 1 and 2 agree well with the simulated pattern according to their single-crystal X-ray data, showing the purity of the synthesized products (Figure S1). Because 1 is isostructural with 2, we describe the thermogravimetric analysis of 2 representatively. Thermogravimetric analysis of 2 showed a weight loss of 31.41% before 250 °C, corresponding to the loss of all guest molecules (calculated 30.56%) (Figure S2). The framework started to collapse and decompose with increasing temperature. The final residue was ZnO (experimental 25.01%, calculated 24.20%). Compound 2 was rinsed with DMF followed by methanol in an experiment to give methanol-exchanged compound. The methanol-exchanged compound was dried at 120 °C under high vacuum for 10 h to give activated 2. The PXRD pattern indicated that the original framework of activated 2 was retained after activation (Figure S3). The characteristic peak of CO of DMF at 1666 cm-1 disappeared for activated 2, suggesting all DMF molecules are removed completely (Figure S4). The permanent porosity of activated 2 can be confirmed by N2 sorption at 77 K, showing type I sorption behavior (Figure S5). The Brunauer-Emmett-Teller (BET) surface area for 2 was calculated to be 407 m2⋅g-1.

elements.content: The fluorescent spectra of 1 and 2 in the solid state have been investigated at room temperature (Figure S6). Upon excitation at 360 nm, 1 shows strong emission at 402 nm with a quantum yield of 7.64%. The fluorescent emission maximum of 2 occurs at 434 nm upon excitation at 360 nm. The quantum yield of 2 is 45.17%, which is higher than that of the reported transition MOF sensor for nitro explosives. To check the nitro explosives sensing properties of two MOFs, fluorescence quenching titration experiments have been performed with dispersed 1 and 2 by gradual addition of 1 mM DMF solutions of 2,4,6-trinitrophenol (TNP). Fluorescence spectra for activated 1 reveal a quenching efficiency (63%) for TNP upon incremental addition of 1 mM (300 μL) analyte (a), while activated 2 shows high quenching efficiency (94%) after addition of the same amount of analyte (c). The quenching efficiency of 2 is among the highest reported for MOFs sensing TNP. Furthermore, addition of TNP solution to the dispersion of activated 2 in DMF causes fluorescence intensity quenching with red-shifted emission maxima (b). The emission spectra of activated 2 exhibit red shifts of 30 nm compared to pure DMF. The red shift becomes higher with increasing TNP concentration (a and Figure S9), while addition of the same amount of TNP only alters the initial emission intensity of activated 1. Up to now, although some fluorescence MOFs have been synthesized and explored for sensing nitro aromatics, most sensors are solely monitored optical signal “turn-off” by emission quenching. Such MOF sensors reveal intrinsic limitations, such as lacking sufficient chemical selectivity and accuracy for a specific analyte. A change in spectral shift can be utilized as another sensing parameter, but utilizing this parameter for TNP detection has been much less reported. Compound 2 was able to detect TNP by virtue of the changes in both emission intensity and spectra shift. Additionally, the BET surface area for activated 2 was calculated to be 407 m2·g–1. After sensing TNP, there is almost no adsorption of N2 molecules, indicating that TNP analyte was adsorbed into the pores of 2.

elements.content: (a) Fluorescence spectra of 1 and 2 upon adding 300 μL of TNP solution (1 mM) in DMF. (b) Normalized emission spectra of 2 in DMF solution upon adding 300 μL of TNP solution (1 mM). (c) Fluorescence quenching efficiencies upon incremental addition of TNP solution. (d) Stern–Volmer plots of I 0/I versus TNP concentration.

(b) Normalized emission spectra of 2 in DMF solution upon adding 300 μL of TNP solution (1 mM). (c) Fluorescence quenching efficiencies upon incremental addition of TNP solution. (d) Stern-Volmer plots of I 0/I versus TNP concentration.

elements.content: (a) Change in emission intensity of 2 with incremental addition of TNP. (b) Digital photographs of solutions of 2 in the presence of different nitro analytes under portable UV light.
elements.clean_text: 4  (a) Change in emission intensity of 2 with incremental addition of TNP. (b) Digital photographs of solutions of 2 in the presence of different nitro analytes under portable UV light.

elements.content: The quenching efficiency can be quantitatively analyzed by use of the Stern–Volmer equation: I 0/I = K SV[A] + 1, where I 0 and I are the emission intensities before and after addition of nitro analyte, respectively; [A] is the concentration of nitro analyte; and K SV is the quenching constant. K SV is calculated via luminescent data. The K SV for 1 is 1.69 × 104 M–1, but the K SV for 2 was calculated to be 6.19 × 104 M–1 (d). To best of our knowledge, this value is higher than any of those found for MOF-based sensors for TNP (Table S2). Notably, the K SV of 2 is about 3.6 times that of 1. These experimental results show that 2 shows high selective detection toward TNP compared to the parent Zn-MOF, which is well consistent with the theoretical calculation results. In addition, the detection limit of 2 for sensing TNP was estimated to be 5.6 × 10–7 M (Figure S7, Tables S3 and S4), which is moderate among the previously reported MOF sensors for TNP (Table S2). Encouraged by the low detection limit and high quenching constant, we explored the trace quantity detection of TNP. Compound 2 responded rapidly to TNP vapor, and the quenching maximum percentage nearly reached 31% (Figure S8).
elements.clean_text: The quenching efficiency can be quantitatively analyzed by use of the Stern-Volmer equation: I 0/I = K SV[A] + 1, where I 0 and I are the emission intensities before and after addition of nitro analyte, respectively; [A] is the concentration of nitro analyte; and K SV is the quenching constant. K SV is calculated via luminescent data. The K SV for 1 is 1.69 × 104 M-1, but the K SV for 2 was calculated to be 6.19 × 104 M-1 (d). To best of our knowledge, this value is higher than any of those found for MOF-based sensors for TNP (Table S2). Notably, the K SV of 2 is about 3.6 times that of 1. These experimental results show that 2 shows high selective detection toward TNP compared to the parent Zn-MOF, which is well consistent with the theoretical calculation results. In addition, the detection limit of 2 for sensing TNP was estimated to be 5.6 × 10-7 M (Figure S7, Tables S3 and S4), which is moderate among the previously reported MOF sensors for TNP (Table S2). Encouraged by the low detection limit and high quenching constant, we explored the trace quantity detection of TNP. Compound 2 responded rapidly to TNP vapor, and the quenching maximum percentage nearly reached 31% (Figure S8).

elements.content: Fluorescence quenching titrations for 2 were also performed with other nitro explosives such as 2,4-dinitrotoluene (2,4-DNT), 2,6-DNT, DNB, nitrobenzene (NB), and 4-nitrotoluene (NT). Some other aliphatic nitro compounds like nitromethane (NM) and nitroethane (NE) were also examined. The changes in emission intensity for other nitro explosives were extraordinarily low (b and Figures S10–S16). Additionally, PXRD pattern indicated that 2 can maintain its crystallinity upon treatment with different nitro explosives solutions (Figure S17). The results demonstrate that activated 2 shows high selective detection toward TNP over other nitro explosives. Enthused by these outcomes for 2, we checked the selectivity for TNP in the presence of other nitro explosives. The emission spectrum for activated 2 dispersed in DMF solution was monitored upon sequential addition of 2,4-DNT solution (40 μL in two equal portions), resulted in negligible emission quenching. Adding an equal amount of TNP solution gave rise to significant fluorescence intensity quenching. The trend was also repeated in the following addition cycles, and the fluorescence intensity quenching phenomenon of TNP was unchanged ( and Figure S19). Other nitro explosives have similar results and phenomena (Figures S18–S25). Highly selective and sensitive detection in the presence of other nitro explosives makes 2 a reliable and efficient sensor for TNP.

Some other aliphatic nitro compounds like nitromethane (NM) and nitroethane (NE) were also examined. The changes in emission intensity for other nitro explosives were extraordinarily low (b and Figures S10-S16). Additionally, PXRD pattern indicated that 2 can maintain its crystallinity upon treatment with different nitro explosives solutions (Figure S17). The results demonstrate that activated 2 shows high selective detection toward TNP over other nitro explosives. Enthused by these outcomes for 2, we checked the selectivity for TNP in the presence of other nitro explosives. The trend was also repeated in the following addition cycles, and the fluorescence intensity quenching phenomenon of TNP was unchanged ( and Figure S19). Other nitro explosives have similar results and phenomena (Figures S18-S25). Highly selective and sensitive detection in the presence of other nitro explosives makes 2 a reliable and efficient sensor for TNP.

elements.content: We also investigates the recyclability of 2 that can be recovered by centrifugation, followed by washing methanol several times. The emission intensity and quenching efficiency of 2 exhibited little change after being used for four cycles. As demonstrated by PXRD measurements, the framework of recovered sample maintained its crystallinity compared with the original one. These results indicate that 2 has recyclable ability (Figure S26).
elements.clean_text: We also investigates the recyclability of 2 that can be recovered by centrifugation, followed by washing methanol several times. The emission intensity and quenching efficiency of 2 exhibited little change after being used for four cycles. As demonstrated by PXRD measurements, the framework of recovered sample maintained its crystallinity compared with the original one. These results indicate that 2 has recyclable ability (Figure S26).

elements.content: To gain further insight into the outstanding sensing mechanism of activated 2, the electronic properties of both nitro analytes and MOF were analyzed. The emission quenching mechanism, through electron transfer from the conduction band of MOFs to the lowest unoccupied molecular orbitals (LUMOs) of electron-deficient nitro explosives, has been well-established. MOFs, especially in the present case involving d10 metal ions, have a narrow energy band owing to their extended network structure and highly localized electronic system. The electron-rich MOFs lie at higher energies than the LUMOs of electron-deficient nitro explosives, allowing transfer of the excited-state electron from the conduction band (CB) to the LUMOs of the nitro explosives. This can result in emission quenching upon excitation. The observed maximum emission quenching is due to the lowest LUMO energy level of TNP (Table S5). However, the order of observed quenching response (TNP > NT > 2,4-DNT > 2,6-DNT > 1,3-DNB > NB > NM > NE) is not in full agreement with the trend of electron deficiency. This clearly indicates that electron transfer process is not the sole emission quenching mechanism. Another possible reason for emission quenching may be the long-range energy-transfer mechanism. The degree of energy transfer heavily relies on spectral overlap between the adsorption band of nitro explosives and the emission spectrum of MOFs. The greater the extent of spectral overlap, the higher the degree of energy transfer. shows that TNP and 2 have the greatest spectral overlap, thus leading to a red shift in the emission maxima with increasing TNP, whereas almost no overlap was found for other nitro analytes. The nonlinear Stern–Volmer plot for TNP suggests energy transfer between the TNP molecule and MOF or a combination of static and dynamic quenching processes involved in emission quenching (Figure S27). The decay time of MOFs upon adding different amounts of TNP can differentiate static and dynamic quenching process. In a static mechanism, the decay time remains unchanged with increasing TNP concentration. However, in a dynamic mechanism, the decay time will be reduced. We examined the decay time of 2 before and after adding TNP analyte (Figure S28). The decay time remained unchanged after adding 300 μL of TNP, suggesting the presence of a static quenching mechanism. To get deeper insight, we measured the UV adsorption spectrum of 2 before and after adding TNP analyte (Figure S29). The results show that a new band at 430 nm appeared, which further supports the static mechanism. Additionally, the strong hydrogen-bond interactions between the amino group of bdc-NH2 ligand and the hydroxyl group of TNP also contribute to emission quenching, as confirmed by the above theoretical calculation results. Some other analytes possessing hydroxyl groups2,4-dinitrophenol (2,4-DNP), 4-nitrophenol (NP), and phenolwere also examined (Figures S30–S32). The order of observed quenching response was TNP > 2,4-DNT > NP > phenol, which is well consistent with the sequence of acidity. However, other nitro analytes have no acidic hydroxyl group to interact with amino groups within the framework, so they show very low quenching effects. Hence, 2 shows highly selective and sensitive detection of TNP in the presence of other nitro explosives, owing to the occurrence of electron-transfer and energy-transfer processes in addition to hydrogen-bond interactions.

MOFs, especially in the present case involving d10 metal ions, have a narrow energy band owing to their extended network structure and highly localized electronic system. The electron-rich MOFs lie at higher energies than the LUMOs of electron-deficient nitro explosives, allowing transfer of the excited-state electron from the conduction band (CB) to the LUMOs of the nitro explosives. The degree of energy transfer heavily relies on spectral overlap between the adsorption band of nitro explosives and the emission spectrum of MOFs. The greater the extent of spectral overlap, the higher the degree of energy transfer.  shows that TNP and 2 have the greatest spectral overlap, thus leading to a red shift in the emission maxima with increasing TNP, whereas almost no overlap was found for other nitro analytes. The nonlinear Stern-Volmer plot for TNP suggests energy transfer between the TNP molecule and MOF or a combination of static and dynamic quenching processes involved in emission quenching (Figure S27). The decay time of MOFs upon adding different amounts of TNP can differentiate static and dynamic quenching process. In a static mechanism, the decay time remains unchanged with increasing TNP concentration. However, in a dynamic mechanism, the decay time will be reduced. However, other nitro analytes have no acidic hydroxyl group to interact with amino groups within the framework, so they show very low quenching effects. Hence, 2 shows highly selective and sensitive detection of TNP in the presence of other nitro explosives, owing to the occurrence of electron-transfer and energy-transfer processes in addition to hydrogen-bond interactions.

elements.content: Extent of spectral overlap between the analyte absorption band and the emission band of 2.
elements.clean_text: 6  Extent of spectral overlap between the analyte absorption band and the emission band of 2.

elements.content: A microporous amino-functionalized MOF, constructed from a nontoxic Zn metal center and mixed ligands, has been designed and synthesized by combining experimental and theoretical methods. The fluorescence explorations showed that the amino-functionalized Zn-MOF can be used to detect TNP with fast response and high effectiveness and sensitivity, even in the presence of other interfering nitro explosives, and it simultaneously shows emission quenching with a red shift of the emission maxima. The outstanding selective detection of TNP can be attributed to the presence of energy- and electron-transfer processes as well as hydrogen-bond interactions between the hydroxyl group of TNP and the amino group of the bdc-NH2 ligand. Clearly, the amino-functionalized MOF shows great potential as a promising fluorescence sensor for selectively sensing TNP. Our results highlight the capabilities of theoretical simulation methods to identify potential MOF materials that are more favorable for nitro explosives detection, providing valuable implications for the experimental synthesis of new MOFs.
elements.clean_text:
Conclusion

A microporous amino-functionalized MOF, constructed from a nontoxic Zn metal center and mixed ligands, has been designed and synthesized by combining experimental and theoretical methods. The fluorescence explorations showed that the amino-functionalized Zn-MOF can be used to detect TNP with fast response and high effectiveness and sensitivity, even in the presence of other interfering nitro explosives, and it simultaneously shows emission quenching with a red shift of the emission maxima. The outstanding selective detection of TNP can be attributed to the presence of energy- and electron-transfer processes as well as hydrogen-bond interactions between the hydroxyl group of TNP and the amino group of the bdc-NH2 ligand. Clearly, the amino-functionalized MOF shows great potential as a promising fluorescence sensor for selectively sensing TNP. Our results highlight the capabilities of theoretical simulation methods to identify potential MOF materials that are more favorable for nitro explosives detection, providing valuable implications for the experimental synthesis of new MOFs.

cln_elements.content:
A mixture of Zn­(NO3)2·6H2O (60 mg, 0.2 mmol), H3bpt (26 mg, 0.1 mmol), and H2bdc (3 mg, 0.015 mmol) in 5 mL of DMF was stirred for 30 min in a vial (20 mL) with the addition of 100 μL of HBF4 (40%). The vial was sealed into a Teflon-lined stainless steel vessel and heated at 120 °C for 3 days. After slow cooling to room temperature, colorless crystals of 1 were collected, washed with DMF, and dried in air. Yield 61% (based on H3bpt). Anal. Calcd (%) for [NH2(CH3)2]­[Zn4O­(bpt)2(bdc)0.5]·5DMF: C, 45.80; H, 4.45; N, 6.28. Found: C, 45.54; H, 4.29; N, 6.01.

Synthesis of <bold>2</bold>

A mixture of Zn­(NO3)2·6H2O (60 mg, 0.2 mmol), H3bpt (26 mg, 0.1 mmol), and H2bdc-NH2 (3 mg, 0.015 mmol) in 5 mL of DMF was stirred for 30 min in a vial (20 mL) with the addition of 50 μL of HBF4 (40%). The vial was sealed into a Teflon-lined stainless steel vessel and heated at 120 °C for 3 days. After slow cooling to room temperature, colorless crystals of 2 were collected, washed with DMF, and dried in air. Yield 57% (based on H3bpt). Anal. Calcd (%) for [NH2(CH3)2]­[Zn4O­(bpt)2(bdc-NH2)0.5]·5DMF: C, 45.54; H, 4.46; N, 6.77. Found: C, 45.40; H, 4.71; N, 6.55.
cln_elements.clean_text:
Experimental Section

Synthesis of 1 

A mixture of Zn(NO3)2⋅6H2O (60 mg, 0.2 mmol), H3bpt (26 mg, 0.1 mmol), and H2bdc (3 mg, 0.015 mmol) in 5 mL of DMF was stirred for 30 min in a vial (20 mL) with the addition of 100 μL of HBF4 (40%). The vial was sealed into a Teflon-lined stainless steel vessel and heated at 120 °C for 3 days. After slow cooling to room temperature, colorless crystals of 1 were collected, washed with DMF, and dried in air. Yield 61% (based on H3bpt). Anal. Calcd (%) for [NH2(CH3)2][Zn4O(bpt)2(bdc)0.5]⋅5DMF: C, 45.80; H, 4.45; N, 6.28. Found: C, 45.54; H, 4.29; N, 6.01.

Synthesis of 2 

A mixture of Zn(NO3)2⋅6H2O (60 mg, 0.2 mmol), H3bpt (26 mg, 0.1 mmol), and H2bdc-NH2 (3 mg, 0.015 mmol) in 5 mL of DMF was stirred for 30 min in a vial (20 mL) with the addition of 50 μL of HBF4 (40%). The vial was sealed into a Teflon-lined stainless steel vessel and heated at 120 °C for 3 days. After slow cooling to room temperature, colorless crystals of 2 were collected, washed with DMF, and dried in air. Yield 57% (based on H3bpt). Anal. Calcd (%) for [NH2(CH3)2][Zn4O(bpt)2(bdc-NH2)0.5]⋅5DMF: C, 45.54; H, 4.46; N, 6.77. Found: C, 45.40; H, 4.71; N, 6.55.

cln_elements.content:
Experimental PXRD patterns of 1 and 2 agree well with the simulated pattern according to their single-crystal X-ray data, showing the purity of the synthesized products (Figure S1). Because 1 is isostructural with 2, we describe the thermogravimetric analysis of 2 representatively. Thermogravimetric analysis of 2 showed a weight loss of 31.41% before 250 °C, corresponding to the loss of all guest molecules (calculated 30.56%) (Figure S2). The framework started to collapse and decompose with increasing temperature. The final residue was ZnO (experimental 25.01%, calculated 24.20%). Compound 2 was rinsed with DMF followed by methanol in an experiment to give methanol-exchanged compound. The methanol-exchanged compound was dried at 120 °C under high vacuum for 10 h to give activated 2. The PXRD pattern indicated that the original framework of activated 2 was retained after activation (Figure S3). The characteristic peak of CO of DMF at 1666 cm–1 disappeared for activated 2, suggesting all DMF molecules are removed completely (Figure S4). The permanent porosity of activated 2 can be confirmed by N2 sorption at 77 K, showing type I sorption behavior (Figure S5). The Brunauer–Emmett–Teller (BET) surface area for 2 was calculated to be 407 m2·g–1.

The fluorescent spectra of 1 and 2 in the solid state have been investigated at room temperature (Figure S6). Upon excitation at 360 nm, 1 shows strong emission at 402 nm with a quantum yield of 7.64%. The fluorescent emission maximum of 2 occurs at 434 nm upon excitation at 360 nm. The quantum yield of 2 is 45.17%, which is higher than that of the reported transition MOF sensor for nitro explosives. To check the nitro explosives sensing properties of two MOFs, fluorescence quenching titration experiments have been performed with dispersed 1 and 2 by gradual addition of 1 mM DMF solutions of 2,4,6-trinitrophenol (TNP). Fluorescence spectra for activated 1 reveal a quenching efficiency (63%) for TNP upon incremental addition of 1 mM (300 μL) analyte (a), while activated 2 shows high quenching efficiency (94%) after addition of the same amount of analyte (c). The quenching efficiency of 2 is among the highest reported for MOFs sensing TNP. Furthermore, addition of TNP solution to the dispersion of activated 2 in DMF causes fluorescence intensity quenching with red-shifted emission maxima (b). The emission spectra of activated 2 exhibit red shifts of 30 nm compared to pure DMF. The red shift becomes higher with increasing TNP concentration (a and Figure S9), while addition of the same amount of TNP only alters the initial emission intensity of activated 1. Up to now, although some fluorescence MOFs have been synthesized and explored for sensing nitro aromatics, most sensors are solely monitored optical signal “turn-off” by emission quenching. Such MOF sensors reveal intrinsic limitations, such as lacking sufficient chemical selectivity and accuracy for a specific analyte. A change in spectral shift can be utilized as another sensing parameter, but utilizing this parameter for TNP detection has been much less reported. Compound 2 was able to detect TNP by virtue of the changes in both emission intensity and spectra shift. Additionally, the BET surface area for activated 2 was calculated to be 407 m2·g–1. After sensing TNP, there is almost no adsorption of N2 molecules, indicating that TNP analyte was adsorbed into the pores of 2.
cln_elements.clean_text:
Experimental PXRD patterns of 1 and 2 agree well with the simulated pattern according to their single-crystal X-ray data, showing the purity of the synthesized products (Figure S1). Because 1 is isostructural with 2, we describe the thermogravimetric analysis of 2 representatively. Thermogravimetric analysis of 2 showed a weight loss of 31.41% before 250 °C, corresponding to the loss of all guest molecules (calculated 30.56%) (Figure S2). The framework started to collapse and decompose with increasing temperature. The final residue was ZnO (experimental 25.01%, calculated 24.20%). Compound 2 was rinsed with DMF followed by methanol in an experiment to give methanol-exchanged compound. The methanol-exchanged compound was dried at 120 °C under high vacuum for 10 h to give activated 2. The PXRD pattern indicated that the original framework of activated 2 was retained after activation (Figure S3). The characteristic peak of CO of DMF at 1666 cm-1 disappeared for activated 2, suggesting all DMF molecules are removed completely (Figure S4). The permanent porosity of activated 2 can be confirmed by N2 sorption at 77 K, showing type I sorption behavior (Figure S5). The Brunauer-Emmett-Teller (BET) surface area for 2 was calculated to be 407 m2⋅g-1.

The fluorescent spectra of 1 and 2 in the solid state have been investigated at room temperature (Figure S6). Upon excitation at 360 nm, 1 shows strong emission at 402 nm with a quantum yield of 7.64%. The fluorescent emission maximum of 2 occurs at 434 nm upon excitation at 360 nm. The quantum yield of 2 is 45.17%, which is higher than that of the reported transition MOF sensor for nitro explosives. To check the nitro explosives sensing properties of two MOFs, fluorescence quenching titration experiments have been performed with dispersed 1 and 2 by gradual addition of 1 mM DMF solutions of 2,4,6-trinitrophenol (TNP). Fluorescence spectra for activated 1 reveal a quenching efficiency (63%) for TNP upon incremental addition of 1 mM (300 μL) analyte (a), while activated 2 shows high quenching efficiency (94%) after addition of the same amount of analyte (c). The quenching efficiency of 2 is among the highest reported for MOFs sensing TNP. Furthermore, addition of TNP solution to the dispersion of activated 2 in DMF causes fluorescence intensity quenching with red-shifted emission maxima (b). The emission spectra of activated 2 exhibit red shifts of 30 nm compared to pure DMF. The red shift becomes higher with increasing TNP concentration (a and Figure S9), while addition of the same amount of TNP only alters the initial emission intensity of activated 1. Up to now, although some fluorescence MOFs have been synthesized and explored for sensing nitro aromatics, most sensors are solely monitored optical signal "turn-off" by emission quenching. Such MOF sensors reveal intrinsic limitations, such as lacking sufficient chemical selectivity and accuracy for a specific analyte. A change in spectral shift can be utilized as another sensing parameter, but utilizing this parameter for TNP detection has been much less reported. Compound 2 was able to detect TNP by virtue of the changes in both emission intensity and spectra shift. Additionally, the BET surface area for activated 2 was calculated to be 407 m2⋅g-1. After sensing TNP, there is almost no adsorption of N2 molecules, indicating that TNP analyte was adsorbed into the pores of 2.

metadata.title:
Rational
Design and Functionalization of a Zinc Metal–Organic
Framework for Highly Selective Detection of 2,4,6-Trinitrophenol
